title: A quick tour of msir
text: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) dimension reduction method based Gaussian finite mixture models provides extension sliced inverse regression (SIR). basis MSIR subspace estimated modeling inverse distribution within slice using Gaussian finite mixtures number components covariance matrix parameterization selected BIC defined user. msir package implements methodology described Scrucca (2011). vignette written R Markdown using knitr package production.
code: library(msir) ## Package 'msir' version 1.4 ## Type 'citation("msir")' for citing this R package in publications.

title: A quick tour of msir
text: obtain rotating 3D spinplot use:

title: A quick tour of msir
code: x1 <- rnorm(100) x2 <- rnorm(100) y  <- 2*x1 + x2^2 + 0.5*rnorm(100) spinplot(x1, y, x2) spinplot(x1, y, x2, scaling="aaa") spinplot(x1, y, x2, rem.lin.trend = "TRUE") spinplot(x1, y, x2, fit.smooth = TRUE) spinplot(x1, y, x2, fit.ols = TRUE) x <- iris[,1:3] y <- iris[,5] spinplot(x) spinplot(x, markby = y) spinplot(x, markby = y, pch = c(0,3,1),           col.points = c("lightcyan", "yellow", "lightgreen"),           background = "black")

title: A quick tour of msir
text: Scrucca, L. (2011) Model-based SIR dimension reduction. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 55(11), 3010-3026.

code: @Article{,   title = {Model-based SIR for dimension reduction},   author = {Luca Scrucca},   journal = {Computational Statistics \& Data Analysis},   year = {2011},   volume = {5},   number = {11},   pages = {3010--3026},   doi = {10.1016/j.csda.2011.05.006}, }

title: Model-Based Sliced Inverse Regression
text: R package implementing model-based sliced inverse regression described Scrucca (2011). Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) dimension reduction method based Gaussian finite mixture models provides extension sliced inverse regression (SIR). basis MSIR subspace estimated modeling inverse distribution within slice using Gaussian finite mixtures number components covariance matrix parameterization selected BIC defined user.

title: Model-Based Sliced Inverse Regression
text: can install released version msir CRAN using: development version GitHub:
code: install.packages("msir") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("luca-scr/msir", build = TRUE, build_opts = c("--no-resave-data", "--no-manual"))

what: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd
code: loess.sd(x, y = NULL, nsigma = 1, ...)  panel.loess(x, y, col = par("col"), bg = NA, pch = par("pch"), cex = 1,              col.smooth = "red", span = 2/3, degree = 2, nsigma = 1, ...)

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd
text: x vector values predictor variable \(x\). y vector values response variable \(y\). nsigma multiplier standard deviation function. col, bg, pch, cex numeric character codes color(s), point type size points; see also par. col.smooth color used lines drawing smooths. span smoothing parameter loess. degree degree polynomials used, see loess. ... argument passed function loess.

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd
text: function loess.sd computes loess smooth mean function mean plus minus k times standard deviation function. function panel.loess can used add scatterplot matrix panel smoothing mean function using loess variability bands plus minus nsigmas times standard deviation.

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd

title: Local Polynomial Regression Fitting with Variability bands — loess.sd
code: data(cars) plot(cars, main = "lowess.sd(cars)") lines(l <- loess.sd(cars)) lines(l$x, l$upper, lty=2) lines(l$x, l$lower, lty=2)

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir-package
text: R package implements MSIR, dimension reduction method based Gaussian finite mixture models. basis subspace estimated modeling inverse distribution within slice using finite mixtures Gaussians, number components covariance matrix parameterization selected BIC defined user. method provides extension sliced inverse regression (SIR) allows overcome main limitation SIR, .e., failure presence regression symmetric relationships, without need impose assumptions.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir-package
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir-package
text: Scrucca, L. (2011) Model-based SIR dimension reduction.  Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 55(11), 3010-3026.

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: BIC-type criterion selecting dimensionality dimension reduction subspace.

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
code: msir.bic(object, type = 1, plot = FALSE)  bicDimRed(M, x, nslices, type = 1, tol = sqrt(.Machine$double.eps))

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: object 'msir' object plot TRUE plot criterion shown. M kernel matrix. See details . x predictors data matrix. See details . type See details . nslices number slices. See details . tol tolerance value

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: BIC-type criterion determination structural dimension selects \(d\) maximizer $$G(d) = l(d) - Penalty(p,d,n)$$ \(l(d)\) log-likelihood dimensions \(d\), \(p\) number predictors, \(n\) sample size. term \(Penalty(p,d,n)\) type penalty used: type = 1: \(Penalty(p,d,n) = -(p-d) \log(n)\) type = 2: \(Penalty(p,d,n) = 0.5 C d (2p-d+1)\), \(C = (0.5 \log(n) + 0.1 n^(1/3))/2  nslices/n\) type = 3: \(Penalty(p,d,n) = 0.5 C d (2p-d+1)\), \(C = \log(n) nslices/n\) type = 4 \(Penalty(p,d,n) = 1/2 d \log(n)\)

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: Returns list components: evalues eigenvalues l log-likelihood crit BIC-type criterion d selected dimensionality msir.bic also assign information corresponding 'msir' object.

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: Zhu, Miao Peng (2006) "Sliced Inverse Regression CDR Space Estimation", JASA. Zhu, Zhu (2007) "kernel method SAVE", Journal Multivariate Analysis.

title: BIC-type criterion for dimensionality — msir.bic
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
text: dimension reduction method based Gaussian finite mixture models provides extension sliced inverse regression (SIR). basis subspace estimated modeling inverse distribution within slice using Gaussian finite mixtures number components covariance matrix parameterization selected BIC defined user.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
code: msir(x, y, nslices = msir.nslices, slice.function = msir.slices,       modelNames = NULL, G = NULL, cov = c("mle", "regularized"), ...)

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
text: x \((n \times p)\) design matrix containing predictors data values. y \((n \times 1)\) vector data values response variable. can numeric vector (regression) also factor (classification). latter case, levels factor define slices used. nslices number slices used, unless y factor. default value returned msir.nslices. slice.function slice functions used, default msir.slices, user can provide different slicing function. modelNames vector character strings indicating Gaussian mixture models fitted described mclustModelNames.  vector strings given used slices. list vectors provided vector refers single slice. G integer vector specifying numbers mixture components used fitting Gaussian mixture models. list vectors provided vector refers single slice. cov predictors marginal covariance matrix. Possible choices : "mle": maximum likelihood estimate "regularized": regularized estimate covariance matrix (see msir.regularizedSigma) R matrix: \((p \times p)\) user defined covariance matrix ... arguments passed msir.compute.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
text: Returns object class 'msir' attributes: call function call. x design matrix. y response vector. slice.info output slicing function. mixmod list finite mixture model objects described  mclustModel. loglik log-likelihood mixture models. f vector length equal total number mixture components containing fraction observations fitted component within slices. mu matrix component within slices predictors means. sigma marginal predictors covariance matrix. M msir kernel matrix. evalues eigenvalues generalized eigen-decomposition M. evectors raw eigenvectors generalized eigen-decomposition M ordered according eigenvalues. basis normalized eigenvectors generalized eigen-decomposition M ordered according eigenvalues. std.basis standardized basis vectors obtained multiplying coefficient eigenvectors standard deviation corresponding predictor. resulting coefficients scaled predictors unit standard deviation. numdir maximal number directions estimated. dir estimated MSIR directions mean-centered predictors.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
text: Scrucca, L. (2011) Model-based SIR dimension reduction. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 55(11), 3010-3026.

title: Model-based Sliced Inverse Regression (MSIR) — msir
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: Approximates marginal dimension test significance levels sampling permutation distribution.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
code: msir.permutation.test(object, npermute = 99, numdir = object$numdir, verbose = TRUE)

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: object 'msir' object. npermute number permutations compute. numdir maximum value dimension test. verbose TRUE textual progress bar shown computation.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: function approximates significance levels marginal dimension tests based permutation test.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: function returns list components: summary table containing hypotheses, test statistics, permutation p-values. npermute number permutations used. Furthermore, also assigns information corresponding 'msir' object.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: Scrucca, L. (2011) Model-based SIR dimension reduction. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 55(11), 3010-3026.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Permutation test for dimensionality — msir.permutation.test
code: if (FALSE) { # 1-dimensional simple regression n <- 200 p <- 5 b <- as.matrix(c(1,-1,rep(0,p-2))) x <- matrix(rnorm(n*p), nrow = n, ncol = p) y <- exp(0.5 * x%*%b) + 0.1*rnorm(n) MSIR <- msir(x, y) msir.permutation.test(MSIR) summary(MSIR) }

what: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma
title: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma
text: function computes regularized version covariance matrix predictors. Among possible models one maximizes BIC returned.

title: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma
code: msir.regularizedSigma(x, inv = FALSE, model = c("XII", "XXI", "XXX"))

title: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma
text: x Ahe predictors data matrix. inv logical specifying must returned. TRUE inverse estimated covariance matrix returned, otherwise estimated covariance matrix (default). model character string specifying available models: XII: diagonal equal variances XXI: diagonal unequal variances XXX: full covariance matrix

title: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma
text: \((p \times p)\) covariance matrix estimate.

title: Regularized estimate of predictors covariance matrix. — msir.regularizedSigma

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
text: Plots directions information MSIR estimation.

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
code: # S3 method for msir plot(x, which,       type = c("pairs", "2Dplot", "spinplot", "evalues", "coefficients"),       span = NULL, std = TRUE, ylab, xlab, restore.par = TRUE, ...)

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
text: x 'msir' object. vector value(s) giving directions plot drawn. type type plot drawn. span span smoother (type = "pairs" | "2Dplot"). std TRUE coefficients standardized (type = "coefficients"). ylab character string y-axis label. xlab character string x-axis label. restore.par TRUE graphical parameters (see par) changed restored previous state. want manipulate resulting plot set restore.par = FALSE. ... additional arguments.

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
text: Scrucca, L. (2011) Model-based SIR dimension reduction. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 55(11), 3010-3026.

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Plot method for 'msir' objects. — plot.msir
code: if (FALSE) { # 2-dimensional response curve n <- 300 p <- 5 b1 <- c(1, 1, 1, rep(0, p-3)) b2 <- c(1,-1,-1, rep(0, p-3)) b <- cbind(b1,b2) x <- matrix(rnorm(n*p), nrow = n, ncol = p) y <- x %*% b1 + (x %*% b1)^3 + 4*(x %*% b2)^2 + rnorm(n) MSIR <- msir(x, y) summary(MSIR) plot(MSIR) plot(MSIR, which = 1:2) plot(MSIR, type = "2Dplot", which = 1, span = 0.7) plot(MSIR, type = "2Dplot", which = 2, span = 0.7) plot(MSIR, type = "spinplot") plot(MSIR, type = "evalues") plot(MSIR, type = "coefficients") }

Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
text: General function draw rgl-based rotating 3D scatterplot.

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
code: spinplot(x, y, z,           scaling = c("abc", "aaa"),           rem.lin.trend = FALSE,           uncor.vars = FALSE,           fit.ols = FALSE,           fit.smooth = FALSE,           span = 0.75,           ngrid = 25,           markby,           pch.points = 1,           col.points = "black",           cex.points = 1,          col.axis   = "gray50",           col.smooth = "limegreen",           col.ols    = "lightsteelblue",          background = "white",           ...)

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
text: x vector values variable horizontal (H) screen axis. y vector values variable vertical (V) screen axis. z vector values variable --screen (O) axis. scaling scaling applied. Two possible values "abc" "aaa". rem.lin.trend logical specifying linear trend remove. TRUE vertical axis replaced e(V|H,O), .e. residuals linear fit vertical axis variable others. uncor.vars logical specifying uncorrelated H O variables used. TRUE O variable replaced e(O|H), .e. residuals regression O H, hence obtaining pair uncorrelated variables. fit.ols logical specifying fitted OLS plane included. fit.smooth logical specifying nonparametric smoothing plane included. span span used loess fit polynomial surface. ngrid number grid points use displaing fitted plane. markby variable (usually factor) used marking points. pch.points vector symbols marking points. col.points vector colors marking points. cex.points cex points. col.axis color axis. col.ols color used drawing OLS plane. col.smooth color used drawing smoothing plane. background color background space. ... catch unused arguments.

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
text: function mainly based functionality spin-plot function available XLisp-Stat software https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XLispStat, adds-introduced Arc software http://www.stat.umn.edu/arc/index.html.

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
text: Cook R. D., Weisberg S. (1999) Applied Regression Including Computing Graphics, Wiley, Chapter 8

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
text: Luca Scrucca luca.scrucca@unipg.

title: Rotating three-dimensional plot — spinplot
code: if (FALSE) { x1 <- rnorm(100) x2 <- rnorm(100) y  <- 2*x1 + x2^2 + 0.5*rnorm(100) spinplot(x1, y, x2) spinplot(x1, y, x2, scaling = "aaa") spinplot(x1, y, x2, rem.lin.trend = "TRUE") spinplot(x1, y, x2, fit.smooth = TRUE) spinplot(x1, y, x2, fit.ols = TRUE)  x <- iris[,1:3] y <- iris[,5] spinplot(x) spinplot(x, markby = y) spinplot(x, markby = y, col.points = c("dodgerblue2", "orange", "green3")) spinplot(x, markby = y, pch = c(0,3,1), col.points = c("dodgerblue2", "orange", "green3"))  # to save plots use  # rgl.postscript("plot.pdf", fmt="pdf") # or # rgl.snapshot("plot.png") }

title: msir 1.4 (2023-02)
text: Changed rgl.* *3d account version 1.0 rgl package. Increased version R required least 4.0.

title: msir 1.3.3 (2020-12)
text: CRAN release: 2020-12-16

title: msir 1.3.2 (2019-03)
text: CRAN release: 2019-03-15 Update vignette. Added website inclusion mclust-org. Fix bug msir.slices(). Fix bug recycling array length 1. rgl package longer dependency suggested.

title: msir 1.3.1 (2016-04)
text: CRAN release: 2016-04-07 Fix issues related NAMESPACE.

title: msir 1.3 (2013-02)
text: CRAN release: 2014-02-24 Removed MASS suggested package since now needed examples help pages. Fixed comments notes package check.

title: msir 1.2 (2012-08)
text: CRAN release: 2012-08-10 Compatibility bug fixes new version 4.0 mclust package. Add verbose argument summary.msir().

title: msir 1.1 (2012-05)
text: CRAN release: 2012-05-30 New mvdnorm() function stable case near singularity covariance matrix. Added byte-code compiling DESCRIPTION file. Corrected msir.components(), now preserves order slices. Introduced possibility control EM algorithm. Bug correction change models’ name msir.regularizedSigma(). 'msir' object returns normalized basis vectors component $basis raw eigenvectors component $evectors. Update reference CSDA paper. Bugs fix.

title: msir 1.0 (2012-05)
text: CRAN release: 2011-05-10 Initial release submitted CRAN.
